Award.AbstractNarration:
Electrons have the fundamental property of "spin," which is analogous to that of a spinning toy top, and is associated with their angular momentum. This project studies collisions between polarized electrons, which have their spins aligned in one direction, and so-called "chiral", or "handed" molecules (such molecules, of which DNA is an example, are characterized by a spiral, or helical geometry). These experiments address physics questions about the dynamics of electron-chiral molecule scattering, particularly with regard to the role played by the electron spins. They will also provide important clues about the origins of biological homochirality--the fact that all naturally-occurring DNA spirals in the same direction. Atoms of zinc are also being used as targets, to check the results of an experiment done recently by an Australian group in which zinc atoms excited by polarized electrons emitted light in a way that is forbidden by all known theories of atomic collisions. If the Australian result is reproduced, much of our basic theoretical knowledge on this topic will be shown to be in error. Improved sources of polarized electrons are also being developed, with the goal of "turnkey" ease of use. This project focuses on two particular ways to make polarized electrons: the first involves electron collisions with rubidium atoms in which spin is transferred from the rubidium to the free electrons. The second uses multiphoton ionization of semiconductors such as gallium arsenide to give the electrons a preferential spin direction. This research done to develop polarized electron technology holds the promise of providing new analytical tools that can be used for biological and materials research, and for industry.

The experiments involving collisions between polarized electrons and chiral molecules will extend previous work that showed chiral sensitivity in both quasi-elastic and reactive scattering with halocamphor targets. Now that such sensitivity has been observed, our goal is to demonstrate such effects in molecules that have biological significance, such as cysteine, and to study the effect of the maximum target nuclear charge and location of the target's chiral center on the chiral asymmetries we observe. The goal in the zinc experiments is to check whether the rather large value of canted linear polarization (polarization fraction P2) observed in fluorescence from excited zinc atoms is reproducible. No extant theory of electron-atom scattering, including the state-of-the-art "R-matrix with pseudostates" approach, has been able to confirm this result, even though they make quantitatively accurate predictions of other collision parameters for this system. Source development work will be based on the successfully demonstrated "rubidium spin-filter" design by our group, in which optically-pumped rubidium undergoes spin-exchange collisions with an incident unpolarized beam of electrons. This project will focus on improving the vacuum system, the rubidium target reliability, and the optical pumping protocol. It will also study a variety of buffer gases to understand the complex physics of the interaction between the electron beam and the rubidium vapor. In the gallium arsenide experiment, unamplified pulses from a femtosecond titanium-sapphire oscillator are used to photo-emit electrons. First experiments will investigate the intensity and polarization of the electrons emitted from bulk gallium arsenide and tip-like gallium arsenide shards. Then targets of gallium arsenide cusp arrays will be considered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Like bolts and nuts, electrons and some molecules have the property of "handedness."  Handed molecules, like DNA, have a helical structure; right-handed molecules are the mirror image of left-handed ones of the same chemical compound.  For a beam of electrons moving in one direction, the right- and left-handed electrons have their spins pointing forward and backward along that direction, respectively.  This award supported experiments that showed, in analogy with the fact that a left-handed bolt cannot be screwed into a right-handed nut (and vice-versa), that electrons with a specific handedness interact differently with the right- and left-handed versions of a given molecule.   The first experiments focused on a chemical reaction in which handed electrons dissociated right- or left-handed molecules of bromocamphor and iodocamphor.  For a given handedness of the electron beam, the bromocamphor breakup rate varied when the molecular handedness was switched from left to right.  Although earlier experiments had shown that handedness would play a role in determining the rate at which these chemical reactions progressed, these new experiments showed that by replacing the heaviest atom in the molecular targets with an even heavier one (iodine replacing bromine), the role of handedness could be enhanced in a predictable way.  However, a second very surprising result was that when the position of the heaviest atom in the molecule was changed to place it at the periphery of the molecular structure, the sensitivity to handedness was doubled.  Simple models of these electron-molecule interactions completely fail to explain increases of this magnitude.  In a second series of experiments, the effect of handedness on simple scattering of the electrons, in which they are deflected from their initial trajectories but do not interact with the targets, was studied.  Understanding the physics of these collisions is still in its infancy; all attempts to explain the totality of the data that have been obtained in terms of simple, unifying mechanisms for the production of the effects of handedness in this broad range of electron-molecule collisions have failed.

Studies of the scattering of polarized electrons by zinc atoms were also done. A beam of polarized electrons is one in which the majority of the electron spins point in a specific direction. When atomic targets are excited by polarized electron impact, they produce fluorescent light when the atom decays that is itself polarized.  Studying these kinds of collisions, a research group at the University of Western Australia observed a polarization signature in the fluorescent light that is forbidden by the basic physics of atomic collections.  Following several re-measurements of the same effect by the Australian group, it was determined that an independent measurement should be made.  Experiments supported by this award failed to reproduce the Australian results and were in agreement with basic theory.

Finally, a ?fast? source of spin-polarized electrons was demonstrated.  Sharp tips of the semiconducting material gallium arsenide (GaAs) were placed in the tight focus of a pulsed laser.  The light pulses had a duration of less than a tenth of a trillionth of a second (75 femtoseconds). By polarizing these laser pulses, it was shown that the electrons photoemitted from the tips by the absorption of three to five photons were themselves polarized.  Moreover, they were ?fast,? meaning that the duration of the emitted electron pulses was comparable (less than 200 femtoseconds) to that of the light pulses that produced them.  Moreover, the process of photoemission did not require that the GaAs tips be specially prepared in an ultra-high vacuum, which is a standard requirement of state-of-the-art  polarized-electron sources.  Short pulses of polarized electrons can be used to study, for example, magnetic transitions in the solid state that take place on very short time scales, or can be used to make ?molecular movies? of chemical reactions that depend on the electron spin of their constituents.  The simplified technology of this fast source means also that it could provide polarized electron technology to many laboratories that previously did not have the wherewithal to do experiments of this type.  A patent application based on this technology has been submitted to the U.S. Patent Office.

Since this award's inception, it has supported one faculty researcher from the University of Nebraska-Kearney, and has has paid for the training of 5 graduate students, 6 undergraduates, and 1 high school student. Another 2 undergraduate students and 1 high school student were supported on an NSF-funded EPSCoR award at Nebraska (Imaging and Controlling Ultrafast Dynamics in Atoms, Molecules, and Nanostructures).
